However, Yusuf Jimmy is ambitious and is hoping that as a result of this loan, he will be able to access quality inputs such as fertilizer and improved seeds that will result in a yield of up to 30 bags of maize per hectare this season.  Yusuf Jimmy is hopeful about what the future holds; he  hopes that with the increased income as a result of a high yield, he will finally be able to afford to educate his children: Jabir and  Zayyad. Yusuf Jimmy’s dreams do not end there: “ultimately, I want to ensure my children are educated and have professional jobs”, he expressed.

loans.use: To purchase high-quality inputs in order to double maize yield and income

loans.name: Waheb

texts.en:
Waheb is a 27-year-old single man, living with his family in their own house in Taiz City, Yemen. Waheb is an educated man with a diploma certificate.  Recently, he is employed as a doctor in the private sector. He is very active and a professional young man, who knows how to manage his life very well. He shares with his parents in covering some of the household expenses. 

Last year, Waheb purchased most of the new furniture and home appliances inside his house. This year he wants to purchase a bedroom set for his house. Unfortunately, he does not have enough money to do that. For this reason, he applied for a Youth loan of 100,000 YER from AMB in order to purchase a bedroom set for his house.

Waheb looks forward to getting married soon. He is a very ambitious young man.

loans.use: to purchase a bedroom set for his house

loans.name: Abubakar Aliyu

texts.en: Abubakar Aliyu is a Babban Gona farmer from Ikara. Abubakar Aliyu expressed that he is driven by one goal: to “make more money for myself and my family.” It is the desire to fulfill this ambition that led Abubakar Aliyu to join Babban Gona. Now, as a Babban Gona member, he finally has the opportunity to access credit, good markets and a trained agronomist. Abubakar Aliyu can earn up to $2000/ha this season from growing maize, more than three times the Nigerian farmer’s average annual income. The average Babban Gona farmer yields 30 bags of maize/hectare, double the national average of 14. However, Abubakar Aliyu, is ambitious and is aiming to reap at least 35 bags per hectare this season. By doing so, Abubakar Aliyu will finally have enough money to make significant life changes. When asked what he plans to do with his income from this season, he said: “I plan to use the money I make to build a better home”. With this loan, Abubakar Aliyu will be able to access all the inputs and services to make this dream a reality.

loans.use: To purchase high-quality inputs in order to double maize yield and income

loans.name: Loise

texts.en:
Loise is 51 years old. She is a hardworking married lady.She is blessed with six children who are all grown-ups. Loise is a green-grocer and also sells paraffin, a business she has done for the last two years, earning a monthly income of Kshs. 10,000.

Loise has requested her first loan with VisionFund Kenya of Kshs. 20,000 which she will use to purchase groceries as well as paraffin for resale.

With the anticipated profits, she will be able to improve the living standards of her family. Her hopes and dreams are to have a stable family as well as business.

loans.use: to purchase groceries as well as paraffin for resale

loans.name: Asma'u Bintu

texts.en: Asma'u Bintu is a Babban Gona farmer from Ikara. Asma'u Bintu expressed that she is driven by one goal: to “make more money for myself and my family.” It is the desire to fulfil this ambition that led Asma'u Bintu to join Babban Gona. Now, as a Babban Gona member, she finally has the opportunity to access credit, good markets and a trained agronomist. Asma'u Bintu can earn up to $2000/ha this season from growing maize, more than three times the Nigerian farmer’s average annual income. The average Babban Gona farmer yields 30 bags of maize/hectare, double the national average of 14. However, Asma'u Bintu, is ambitious and is aiming to reap at least 35 bags per hectare this season. By doing so, Asma'u Bintu will finally have enough money to make significant life changes. When asked what she plans to do with her income from this season, she said: “I plan to use the money I make to build a better home”. With this loan, Asma'u Bintu will be able to access all the inputs and services to make this dream a reality.

loans.use: To purchase high-quality inputs in order to double maize yield and income

loans.name: Agiradence

texts.en: Agiradence, 65 years old,  is married with three children aged between 35 and 52. All of them completed their studies. She has been selling foodstuffs, and with the loan; she would like to buy more beans, sorghum, maize flour and salt. The profit from the business will be used to become a supplier.

loans.use: To buy more beans, sorghum, maize flour and salt for resale.

loans.name: Shemsa Aime

texts.en: Shema Aime, 28 years old, is married and has two children who are one and five years of age. For the past three years, Shema Aime has been selling beans. With this loan, she would like to buy more beans to sell. The profits from the business will help pay school fees and improve the family's welfare.

loans.use: To buy more beans to sell.

loans.name: Hauwa'u Sa'adu

texts.en: Hauwa'u Sa'adu is a 28-year-old farmer from Ikara.  As a Babban Gona member, Hauwa'u Sa'adu is excited about the opportunity to finally have access to credit, good markets and a trained agronomist. Like all Babban Gona members, Hauwa'u Sa'adu can earn up to $2000/ha this season from growing maize, more than three times the Nigerian farmer’s average annual income. The average Babban Gona farmer yields 30 bags/hectare; double the national average of 14. However, Hauwa'u Sa'adu is ambitious and is hoping that as a result of this loan, she will be able to access quality inputs to reap up to 35 bags of maize per hectare this season.  Hauwa'u Sa'adu is hopeful about what the future holds; she  hopes that with the increased income as a result of a high yield, she will finally be able to afford to educate her children: Maryam and  Khadija. Hauwa'u Sa'adu’s dreams do not end there: “ultimately, I want to ensure my children are educated and have professional jobs”, she expressed.

loans.use: To purchase high-quality inputs such as fertilizer and seed in order to double maize yield and income

loans.name: Anonymous Group
loans.use: to purchase construction materials to build other rooms to expand her house

loans.name: 6 De Agosto Group

texts.es:
La A.C. “6 DE AGOSTO” iniciará el cuarto ciclo en Pro Mujer, como parte del Centro Focal de Copacabana, está compuesta por ocho  integrantes y está dirigida por una mesa directiva donde la señora Celestina es la Presidenta. Los negocios que las integrantes de la asociación comunal llevan adelante son variados entre ellos existen: venta de queso, venta de leche, venta de flores, venta de pescado, venta de chuño.
 
El crédito que sacaran beneficiara a pequeñas microempresarias donde la señora Celestina es integrante, ella indica que hace dos años que integra Pro Mujer, ingresando por la invitación de un promotor de la institución que fue a visitarle a su domicilio. En la actualidad ella tiene un negocio de venta de flores; da a conocer que este negocio lo inicia hace varios años, ya que sus padres comercializaban el mismo producto y ella decidió implementarlo después de su matrimonio.
 
El crédito que ahora sacará es para alimento en tiempo de sequía (compra de flores por mayor) que adquirirá de las vendedoras de la Ciudad de El Alto y posteriormente lo comercializará en las comunidades aledañas a su domicilio. Esta forma de trabajo le permite generar recursos para apoyar a su familia, ya que ella es casada.  

Cuando se le consulta qué le gusta de Pro Mujer, ella responde que le gusta el seguro de vida que ofrece la institución.
texts.en:
The 'AUGUST 6" Communal Bank will begin its fourth cycle in Pro Mujer, as part of the Copacabana Regional Office. August 6 consists of eight members and has a board of directors led by the Chairwoman, Señora Celestina. The members run various businesses, including sales of cheese, milk, flowers, fish, and chuño [a regional fruit]. 
 
The group members are applying for loans that will help their microbusinesses, such as Señora Celestina's. She has been a member of Pro Mujer for two years, having joined at the invitation of a Pro Mujer promoter who came to her home. Señora Celestina has for several years run a business selling flowers, as her parents did before her. She decided to follow their example and start her own business after she got married. 
 
Señora Celestina is applying for a loan to get her through the slow season (purchasing wholesale flowers) that she'll buy from sellers in Ciudad de El Alto, then resell in communities near her home. Flower sales allow Señora Celestina to earn the income that supports her family. 

Asked what she likes about Pro Mujer, Señora Celestina replies that the institution has offered her a greater degree of security.

loans.use: to purchase wholesale flowers

loans.name: Marly Fabiola

texts.es: Marly es una joven que hace dos años inicio su propio negocio vendiendo riquísimas tortillas a base de maíz todo para sacar adelante a sus dos pequeños hijos y que no le falte nunca un techo y una alimentación. Marly requiere de un préstamo para construir un servicio sanitario que preste todas las condiciones higiénicas necesarias para que sus hijos crezcan en un ambiente sano e higiénico. Sus principales metas están en cancelar este préstamo para luego solicitar otro nuevo préstamo para invertirlo en su negocio y con las ganancias seguir mejoran las condiciones de su humilde casita.
texts.en: Marly is a young woman who runs a business selling delicious corn tortillas. She started the business two years ago in order to provide for her two children, so that they'll always have food to eat and a roof over their heads. Marley needs a loan to install a bathroom in her home and provide the sanitary conditions her children need to grow up in a healthy environment. Marly's main goals are to pay back this loan and then apply for another one to invest in her business. She wants to use the earnings from the business to keep improving conditions in her family's humble little home.

loans.use: to install a bathroom.

loans.name: Leonard

texts.en: Leonard is age 28. He is married with three children, two of whom go school. He has been selling in a shop and has been running this business for the past five years. With the loan, he would like to buy more items to sell. The profits from the business will be used to pay school fees for the children, to buy foodstuffs and for his savings.

loans.use: To buy soap, biscuits, sugar and salt to sell

loans.name: Jacqueline

texts.en:
Jacqueline is 43 years old. She is married with seven children aged between 22 and 7. All of them go to school. 
She sells saucepans and basins, and has been running this business for the past 12 years. With the loan, Jacqueline would like to buy more saucepans to sell. The profits from the business will be used to pay school fees for their children, to improve their welfare and to reinvest.

loans.use: To buy more saucepans and basins to sell.
